newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end up despite late profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end up despite late profit-taking.

text.p: Taiwan share prices closed slightly higher on Monday despite late profit-taking that eroded early-session gains that were fuelled by a resurgent electronics sector, brokers said.
The weighted index wavered in a narrow range throughout Monday's session to finish a scant 15.96 points or 0.20 percent higher at 8,194.66. Turnover was modest at T$84 billion.
Share prices rose to an intra-day high of 8,248.48 on active buying of electronic shares, which have rebounded from the heavy profit-taking they endured in a recent market correction.
Electronics gained 1.06 percent as a sector.

Asustek Computer Inc jumped the daily seven percent limit, or T$24, to T$373 -- the highest price of any listed share -- on reports that its recent issue of global depository receipts had been well received overseas.
Winbond rose T$1.5 or 4.13 percent to T$37.8.

"There is no doubt electronics will outperform others and become the market's leading sector, but views are divided on how the market's current consolidation will be," National Securities' analyst Alex Yang said.
Investors were cautious as the index neared the technical resistance of 8,250 points, brokers said.
Overall sentiment has improved in part because of the Taiwan government's plan to allow local and foreign institutions to issue warrants on big-capital blue chips in June, brokers said.
As a result, many foreign and domestic funds were buying up warrant-related issues, mostly in big-capital firms, they said.

Under the liberalisation, local and foreign institutions will be allowed to issue warrants on local firms having market value above T$30 billion and having 25 percent or more of their shares circulating in the market. To be eligible, listed firms must have more than 7,500 shareholders.
